Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Broad overview of the political landscape of the Middle East after the uprisings of 2011.
Middle East Politics Understandingreading
After this course, I have a strong background on MENA institutions and the events and consequences of the Arab Spring.
Critical analysis of historical and political materials related to the execution of the Arab spring and its after effects in the Arab world.
Knowledge about the middle east

I learned about the economic and political structures of the Middle East and the nuanced culture of the region that supports them. I also learned how to analyze scholarly papers written about the region and how to understand news reported on the region with all its biases.

As somebody with little prior knowledge of the Middle East or Middle Eastern politics, this was a great class to get introduced to those topics. Also, the class was a great introduction to the study of comparative politics in general, as I previously had mainly only studied American politics.

I learned a lot about the middle east's problems that I haven't been taught or that haven't been talked about since I lived most of my life in the UAE. The course helped me expand my knowledge on the topic and gave me good resources to learn more about how the Arab spring shaped the middle east.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Amazing professor and TA. Course material included a wide variety of readings, films, and lectures.
The course is so great. I really like Professorthe best and most efficient professor I have ever meet. Hope to take her course in the future.

The course was strong overall. Recorded lectures were clear and the material was relevant and interesting. The documentaries were particularly good. My favorite part of our classes were the discussions of current articles toward the end of our meetings.

One of its biggest strength is how the professor and teaching assistant have successfully created this open environment where we are allowed to openly share our thoughts without being too self conscious about being wrong. It makes it easier to actually gain something from the discussions.

Strengths: Professor and content
Weakness: the not in person lectures

The live lectures and discussion sections were very useful in clarifying the material. Because of the shortened class format, there were too many readings each week and it was difficult to engage thoroughly with all of them.

The layout of the class was simple and straightforward, which I thought was very important considering it was only a five-week-long summer class. With such a short course, not having to worry about logistical issues or things like that was very important in getting more benefit out of the class, because it allowed me to focus as much as I could on the actual content of the class. For example: the Canvas site was laid out perfectly and in an extremely organized manner. It was always easy to find readings, weekly quizzes, reading response information, etc.

The short length of the course is not a weakness but it is something that anyone thinking about taking any YSS course should consider. Five weeks is long enough to get a solid introduction to a field or dip into some quality discussion, but it generally does not allow for the same level of depth or nuance as a full semester-long course would. In my opinion, at leas.t
This course was well structured to give a general overview of politics in the Middle East.
my main weakness was the course quizzes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely
YesAbsolutely

Yes, the course is broad and covers a lot of ground in just a few weeks but does it well. If you are interested in learning more about the Arab Spring this is a great chance to do so. If you are deeply familiar with the region it will be redundant.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student especially if they have a thirst to learn about the Arab spring and how it has shaped the Arab world that we see today. Professor Elizabeth Nugent is very passionate about the topic and very knowledgable about the region, it was an honour to be in her class.
Absolutely
Yes! The content is fascinating and the course was taught extremely well.

I would suggest anybody with an interest in comparative politics, the Middle East, or both to take this course. I would not suggest taking this course just to get a credit if you are not truly interested in the material.

Absolutely! This course was fantastically well organized in all sensesthe syllabus didn't change erratically, the topic of the modules all made sense, and every reading was relevant and built on each other. I think I came out of this class with a much better grasp of the complexities of politics in the Middle East, as well as various concepts in academic political science as well.
yes because this course explained the Arab springs consequences and helped me understand the whole region much better.
